questions.neutral: You feel it too - something's off, right?

hobby.message: Antique typewriter giving you trouble again?
Origami helping you dodge the spiral?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me - In free time, I fold origami... from scrap forms mostly. It helps me think - quietly.
neutral_answer: Yeah, something's off. The city doesn't feel the same lately.
I've had to change how I spend my evenings.
Not much point folding paper in the dark, I guess.
It's all... unsettled.
Seems like everyone notices it, even if no one says.
I used to fold paper cranes most nights—keeps me centered.
Power goes out now, hard to do anything by lamp or candle.
Funny, the restored neighbors don't have that problem.
It's like even hobbies need permission these days.
Yeah, I've noticed—things stopped working the way they should.
I do origami at home, intricate patterns, it's sort of meditative.
But with all the rolling blackouts, I keep losing light mid-piece.
Even tried by window for natural light, but that's scarce too.
Restored residents down my hall always seem comfortable—never lose power.
It's hard not to notice who adapts, and who gets left waiting.
You’re right, it’s not just you.
I usually fold complex origami—modular stuff, takes hours per model.
Now, half my evenings get cut short if my block loses power.
Last week, I ruined a tessellation during an outage—my hands wouldn't stop shaking.
Galina’s place was lit up bright, like nothing changed for her.
Maybe I’m just bitter, but it feels scripted—some of us improvising, others get stage lighting.
Folding paper used to help me control the chaos, but now it’s part of it.
Definitely off. You notice the patterns after a while—like origami, layer by layer.
I make models from old compliance forms, mostly to keep my mind steady.
Used to fold all night, just for the click of the crease—felt grounded.
These power issues... last Sunday, lost light mid-fold, ruined a dragon’s face.
Meanwhile, the restored people? Power, heat, they can even lodge requests—mine get denied.
Sometimes I think they’re being reshuffled, like folding the same paper till it weakens.
Strange—I measure my days by what I fold, now I measure by what interruptions I can work through.
I never thought a ‘harmless’ hobby would show me which side of the line I’m on.
hobby_answer: Yeah, mostly. Folding helps, when things are—loud.
Haven't had much light lately though.
Outages make the details hard to see.
No big projects—just scraps, quick folds.
Less time for it, with all these system issues.
It does, usually. Patterns distract me from the chatter.
Outages make evenings tricky now; hard to see the creases.
Last night, half my block was dark, except the restored units.
I've been sticking to simple shapes, easy to finish in half-light.
Feels like even the little routines get interrupted lately.
Just less patience, maybe.
Origami helps, keeps the system noise in the background.
Used to fold cranes every Saturday with proper lighting.
Now, power cuts mean working by the window, if there's any daylight.
Galina's flat stayed lit this time—mine didn't.
Trying more basic models, since night folds turn out messy.
Restored neighbors offer candles, but it's awkward taking help.
Just strange, folding while everything else is failing.
It does help, especially when things keep glitching.
Saturday, power went out again; I tried folding by the window.
Supposed to do a tessellated crane, but botched it in the dark.
Galina's lights stayed on, made the rest of us look like shadows.
Funny—restored neighbors hand out BCI leaflets, like paper can fix the grid.
I've started keeping failed folds as reminders of these odd nights.
It used to be my way to unwind, now it's—frustration practice.
Sometimes I wonder if even the origami's getting scored.
Absolutely, it's my anchor—been folding since before the BCI even existed.
Used to lose hours making modular arcs, now I ration candle stubs.
Saturday proved it—whole block dark but restored ones practically hosting parties.
You notice who gets solutions and who gets stuck—most just adapt, I guess.
Tried making a complex jun-mai rose, but hands were too numb from cold.
I track mistake folds in a notebook, like an audit of failure rates.
The system even flags lateness to my hobby group now—like leisure is data.
Origami used to make the world smaller, quieter; now it's the only thing I control at all.
Sometimes I fold little encrypted messages into the paper, not for anyone—just so I know I tried.
